facts.one: The first stadium in Europe with a sliding roof, it was originally called the Amsterdam ArenA
facts.two: The venue was renamed Johan Cruijff ArenA in 2018 in honour of Ajax's former player and coach
facts.three: The 1998 UEFA Champions League final between Real Madrid & Juventus was staged here aswell as the 2013 Europa League Final where Chelsea beat Benfica
facts.four: The stadium Hosted five matches during UEFA EURO 2000, including the Netherlands' semi-final shoot-out defeat by Italy.

facts.one: The Olympic Stadium was completed in 2015
facts.two: 2019 Europa League Final will be staged here
facts.three: The President of Azerbaijan, and those of FIFA and UEFA, attended a ceremony to lay the first stone of the stadium on 6 June 2011, as part of celebrations marking 100 years of Azerbaijani football.
facts.four: Azerbaijan hope to one day host the Olympic games in this stadium.

facts.one: Opened in 2013, the new stadium replaced the old Estadio de San Mamés which was built in 1913 and staged games at the 1982 FIFA World Cup.
facts.two: The new venue hosted the 2018 European Rugby Challenge Cup and Champions Cup finals before holding matches at UEFA EURO 2020.
facts.three: A statue of goalscoring legend Pichichi was moved from the old stadium to the new; visiting club captains traditionally present a bouquet at the statue to mark their first visit.
facts.four: The stadium can be illuminated from the outside.

facts.one: Completed in 2011, the National Arena stands on the site of the old National Stadum
facts.two: The stadium's biggest event to date was the 2012 UEFA Europa League final, where Atlético Madrid beat Athletic Bilbao 3-0.
facts.three: The National Arena is around 4km from central Bucharest and 7km from the main railway station
facts.four: The st=adium has a retractable roof

facts.one: Work began on Budapest's new stadium, named after its most famous footballing export, in 2016 and is expected to finish in 2019
facts.two: The completed venue will have an all-seated capacity of over 65,000, and it will become the new home of the Hungarian national team.
facts.three: The old ground witnessed England's heaviest international defeat; they lost 7-1 to Hungary on 23 May 1954.
facts.four: Non-footballing stars to have played at the original venue include Queen, Genesis, U2, Guns'n'Roses, the Rolling Stones, Michael Jackson and Depeche Mode.

facts.one: Parken Stadium is the largest football stadium in Denmark
facts.two: Hosted the 1994 European Cup Winners' Cup final and the UEFA Cup final six years later, both involving Arsenal.
facts.three: The home of FC København and the senior men's national team.
facts.four: Completed in 1992, the stadium is located just north of the city centre, roughly 4km from the main train station

facts.one: The venue stands on the site of the old Lansdowne Road ground, which had been, for the most part, the Irish football team's stadium of choice since the 1980s.
facts.two: There was also only one goal scored when, in 2011, the Dublin Arena staged the all-Portuguese UEFA Europa League final, Radamel Falcao getting Porto's winner against Braga.
facts.three: Ángel Di María's 20th-minute strike in Argentina's 1-0 friendly win over Ireland on 11 August 2010 was the first international goal at the new arena
facts.four: The stadium is located in the Ballsbridge area on Dublin just a 20 minute walk from the city centre. The stadium has it's own rail station

facts.one: The world's biggest stadium from 1908-50, Hampden Park held a crowd of 149,415 for a 1937 Scotland v England match.
facts.two: Hampden Park held one of the great European Cup finals – Real Madrid's 7-3 defeat of Eintracht Frankfurt in 1960.
facts.three: It also witnessed one of the outstanding UEFA Champions League final goals: Zinédine Zidane's volley against Leverkusen in Real Madrid's 2002 success.
facts.four: City giants Celtic and Rangers have their own stadiums; Hampden Park is home to the Scottish national team and amateur side Queens Park

facts.one: Wembley, the UK's largest stadium and home to the English Football Association, has welcomed over 21 million visitors since reopening in 2007.
facts.two: The original Wembley staged five European Cup finals, plus the finals of the 1966 FIFA World Cup and 'EURO 96.
facts.three: With its complete reconstruction, from 2003–07, a gigantic arch replaced the twin towers as the 90,000-capacity venue's visual hook.
facts.four: The new stadium held its first UEFA Champions League finals in 2011 and 2013.

facts.one: Home of Bayern München, the Allianz Arena was completed in April 2005, in time to stage games at the 2006 FIFA World Cup.
facts.two: Accessible by underground train, the stadium lies on Werner-Heisenberg-Allee, named after a German atomic physicist and 1932 Nobel Prize for Physics winner.
facts.three: The stadium's outer shell consists of diamond-shaped foil panels, lit from within by LED lights, which can shine in 16 million different colours.
facts.four: The stadium staged the 2012 UEFA Champions League final, which Bayern lost to Chelsea on penalties after a 1-1 draw.

facts.one: The Stadium has staged four European Champion Clubs' Cup finals: 1977, 1984, 1996 and 2009.
facts.two: Hosted the Olympics in 1960 and the finals of the 1968 UEFA European Championship and 1990 FIFA World Cup, as well as a number of Italy matches.
facts.three: Lazio and Roma share the stadium, although both clubs plan to have their own purpose-built arenas in the future.
facts.four: The stadium is part of the Foro Italico sport complex, which also features the beautiful Stadio dei Marmi as well as a swimming stadium and tennis centre.

facts.one: Zenit moved there from Petrovsky Stadium in April 2017, beating Ural Sverdlovsk Oblast 2-0 in their first game.
facts.two: The arena hosted four matches at the 2017 FIFA Confederations Cup, including the final, and staged seven fixtures at the 2018 FIFA World Cup.
facts.three: The venue was designed by Japanese architect Kisho Kurokawa, whose vision was for a spaceship that had landed on the shores of the Gulf of Finland.
facts.four: The nearest metro station is Krestovsky Ostrov on the purple line, which runs through central Saint Petersburg.
